summary.para: The GetAverageFrameSize method retrieves the average size of the frames that the filter has captured.

param.name: plAverageSize
param.para: Pointer to a variable that receives the average frame size, in bytes, since the filter began streaming.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

remarks.para: If the device does not report a value, the method might succeed but return zero in the plAverageSize parameter.

summary.para: The GetDroppedInfo method retrieves an array of frame numbers that were dropped.

param.name: lSize
param.para: Specifies the size of the array.

param.name: plArray
param.para: Pointer to an array of size lSize, allocated by the caller. The method fills the array with the frame numbers of the first lSize frames that were dropped, up to a maximum number that is device-dependent.

param.name: plNumCopied
param.para: Pointer to a variable that receives the number of items returned in plArray. This number might be less than the value of lSize.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

description.para: Invalid argument; the lSize parameter must by greater than zero.

summary.para: The GetNumDropped method retrieves the total number of frames that the filter has dropped since it started streaming.

param.name: plDropped
param.para: Pointer to a variable that receives the number of dropped frames.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

remarks.para: The filter resets the count to zero when it transitions from stopped to paused.

If your application uses the interface to control a pin, the driver might continue to count dropped and non-dropped frames while the pin is off. To get an accurate count, call this method once when you turn on the pin, and again when you turn off the pin. The difference is the total number of dropped frames. (If the start time occurs later than the call to , the application should listen for the EC_STREAM_CONTROL_STARTED event.) These remarks also apply if your application uses the method.

summary.para: The IAMDroppedFrames interface retrieves performance information from a video capture filter, including how many frames were dropped and how many were delivered. Applications can use this interface to determine capture performance at run-time.

remarks.para: Some filters that expose this interface do not implement the or method.

For Windows Driver Model (WDM) devices, the WDM Video Capture Filter automatically exposes this interface if the WDM driver supports the PROPSETID_VIDCAP_DROPPEDFRAMES property set. For more information, see the Windows Driver Kit (WDK) documentation.

The number of dropped frames is reported by the capture driver. This information is not directly correlated with any particular media sample, so it is not accurate on a per-frame basis, although it should be accurate over time.
